Award.AwardTitle: Transforming STEM assessment methodologies: Research on cyber-enabled measurement of cognitive models of natural selection

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration:
The investigators propose to develop a form of assessment in natural selection -- and a computer based system to implement such -- that would use Latent Semantic Analysis (LSA) and hot term extraction as a means of transforming rich, open ended student responses into scores that are usable by faculty yet retain the complexities of the learning assessed.

The LSA approach will be compared to interview and multiple choice methods of assessment. Some comparative cost analysis will be performed. The project will be performed at OSU with undergraduates (both white students and students from underrepresented racial and ethnic groups).

Should this research be successful, it will create a new and more informative way to assess students? knowledge -- one that takes into account all the knowledge he/she brings to bear on the study of STEM education. This could provide instructors, and the students themselves, with more helpful and powerful information to improve teaching methods and learning approaches, respectively.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Within K-12 and university education, the scientific concept of natural selection serves as a unifying idea that provides curricular coherence for the life science strands of the National Science Education Standards as well as many state standards, university departments, and research programs. Despite the unequivocal recognition of natural selection as a core piece of STEM content, learners at all levels of the educational hierarchy in the United States—from high school to medical school—are characterized by low levels of understanding of natural selection, as well as myriad misconceptions. Despite widespread concern about low levels of biological literacy in US students, remarkably little attention has focused on the development of rich and rigorous methods for detecting and diagnosing student understanding so that particular pedagogical strategies used to teach natural selection at different levels within the educational hierarchy can be evaluated. This project harnessed the expertise of researchers from science education, psychometrics, computer science/machine learning, biology education, and evolutionary biology to produce new and innovative tools for assessing student understanding of natural selection at the undergraduate level. These tools were shown to be more accurate (valid) that current multiple-choice assessment methods. The new assessment tools are now freely available on the Internet and are backed by more than 30 peer-reviewed studies. The project also brought together researchers from different disciplines to tackle the complex task of automatically analyzing students’ written text about natural selection, and helped to prepare future researchers (graduate students) to work effectively across disciplinary boundaries.
